acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96-hour LC50 = 37.8 mg/L for fish (fathead minnow) (AQUIRE, 2008), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Harmful to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its classification for acute toxicity is Category 3 and it is not rapidly degradable (non-biodegradable, BOD degradability: 1% (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1988)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Since its flash point is 58degC (Hommel (1996), which is between 23 and 60degC, the substance was classified into Category 3.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Since there are no in vivo mutagenicity test results available, or no positive results in in vitro mutagenicity tests using several indices, classification is not possible. Regarding in vitro mutagenicity tests, Ames tests gave negative results (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council), accessed in September 2008) while chromosomal aberration tests using CHL cells gave positive results (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council), accessed in September 2008).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Its autoignition point is 410degC (Hommel (1996)), which is above 70degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Draize tests using rabbits found that the substance is severely irritating (RTECS (2008)) and is in Category 1 for skin irritation. Thus, it was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Draize tests using rabbits gave score 4 or higher in response to the test substance, indicating that it is severely irritating (ECETOC TR 66 (1995)). Thus, it was classified into Category 1. It is rated as R34 in the EU classification.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In 28-day forced oral administration tests using rats, NOEL was found to be 50 mg/kg/day (90-day corrected dose: 15.5 mg/kg/day) for both sexes (Toxicity Testing Reports of Environmental Chemicals (Chemicals Investigation Promoting Council), accessed in September 2008), and no notable effects of administration were detected except for slight changes in organ weights and biochemical measurements at 100 and 200 mg/kg (90-day corrected dose: 33.3 mg/kg/day and 66.6 mg/kg/day, respectively), which fall under Category 2 guidance doses. In contrast, in rats that underwent 90-day inhalation exposure at 0.15 mg/L, which falls under Category 1 guidance values, adipose degeneration in the liver and renal tubule degeneration in the kidney were noted (RTECS (2008)). Similarly, in other inhalation exposure tests using rats, renal tubule degeneration in the kidney was detected after 6 months of exposure to the concentration of 0.035 mg/L, which falls under Category 1 guidance values (RTECS (2008)). However, because these results were acquired using List 3 datasets, and no other information is available, classification is not possible.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
